prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to reach the desired sensitivity of our continuum observation with the lowest integration time, we request the full ALMA bandwidth of 7.5GHz.

As the SWIFT XRT source position has an uncertainty of about 7.5 arcsec, it is possible that the radio counterpart is not located at the pointing position but rather within the area given by this positional uncertainty. Hence, we want to be able to image this region. At the same time, the requested resolution would provide a significantly improved positional accuracy.
In order to have a robust detection we aim to reach a signal-to-noise ratio of 10, factoring in a resonable uncertainty in the extrapolated flux density.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 2FGL J1847.2-0236 100GHz (XRT Source A)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: For this gamma-ray source 2 X-ray sources are detected. Since we use the X-ray coordinates as pointing positions for ALMA, in this science goal, we address X-ray source A. Since blazars are expected to show flat/inverted spectra, ALMA spectral index information of both sources will allow us to constrain the gamma-ray counterpart.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to reach the desired sensitivity of our continuum observation with the lowest integration time, we request the full ALMA bandwidth of 7.5GHz.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: About 30% of all gamma-ray sources detected by Fermi/LAT are still unidentified, i.e. they lack at least one low energy counterpart. The identification of these highly energetic sources is one of the four main scientific objectives of the Fermi/LAT mission. The largest population of associated gamma-ray sources are blazars. However, due to absorption, scattering, and source confusion, less gamma-ray blazars are found close to the Galactic plane as expected for an isotropic distribution. With this exploratory study, we propose ALMA observations at 100 GHz and 230 GHz of 5 unassociated gamma-ray sources at low galactic latitude with no radio counterpart to confirm their nature as hidden blazars. These sources are broadband emitters, such that we select only sources which have possible X-ray counterparts from Swift/XRT observations. Our proposed study will be the first step toward a better understanding of different populations of gamma-ray sources. It will open a new window for their investigation using high radio frequencies, having a high potential to discover new gamma-ray source classes.
